paper_abstract: In this paper we study the randomness complexity needed to distributively perform k XOR computations in a t-private way using constant-round protocols in the case in which the players are honest but curious. We show that the existence of a particular family of subsets allows the recycling of random bits for constant-round private protocols. More precisely, we show that after a 1-round initialization phase during which random bits are distributed among n players, it is possible to perform each of the k XOR computations using two rounds of communication. For t <= c root n/log n, for any c < 1/2, we design a protocol that uses O(kt(2) log n) random bits.
